columns.text: In this exercise, as a prospective borrower, we'll determine which bank offers the best loan if First National Bank offers a 13.1% interest rate monthly compounded and First United Bank charges 13.4% but compounded semiannually.
We'll compute and compare the effective annual rates offered by the two banks to discover which bank is favorable to acquire a loan.

Let's start with defining the effective annual rate.

The rate calculated by factoring in the nominal interest rate and the compounding period is known as the Effective Annual Rate (EAR). The EAR refers to the loan's actual rate, taking into account the compounding of the interest rate.

The effective annual rate (EAR) is calculated using the following formula:

$$ \begin{aligned}
EAR &=\left(1+\dfrac{APR}{m}\right)^m-1
\end{aligned}$$

Where:

$EAR$, which means the effective annual rate\
$APR$, which represent the annual percentage rate\
$m$, which indicated the period
The annual percentage rate refers to the stated rate commonly quoted by lenders. In this case, the annual percentage rate or the nominal rate is the interest rate stated by both of the banks.

Let's start by calculating First National Bank's effective annual rate of the loan. In our calculations, we'll take into account the following:

| Particulars            |             |
|------------------------|-------------|
| Annual percentage rate | 13.1%       |
| Period                 | 12 (months) |

Applying the effective annual rate formula, let's determine the effective rate.

$$ \begin{aligned}
EAR &=\left(1+\dfrac{0.131}{12}\right)^{12}-1
\\[10pt]
&=1.1392-1
\\[5pt]
&= \boxed{\bf13.92\%}
\end{aligned}$$

As can be seen in our calculation, the effective annual rate of First National Bank is 13.92%.

Next, let's calculate the effective annual rate of First United Bank using the same formula and applications. We'll consider the following factors in our calculations:

| Particulars            |             |
|------------------------|-------------|
| Annual percentage rate | 13.4%       |
| Period                 | 2 (semiannual) |

Let's figure out the effective rate using the effective annual rate formula.

$$ \begin{aligned}
EAR &=\left(1+\dfrac{0.134}{2}\right)^{2}-1
\\[10pt]
&=1.1385-1
\\[5pt]
&= \boxed{\bf13.85\%}
\end{aligned}$$

Based on our calculation, the effective annual rate offered by First United Bank is 13.85%.

When comparing the two banks' effective rates, the First National Bank has a 13.92% rate while the First United Bank has a 13.85% rate. We'll go with the bank with the lowest interest rate, resulting in lower payments.

**As a result, we may determine that First United Bank is the best option for acquiring the loan.**

To conclude, although First United Bank has a higher stated rate than First National Bank, we determined by calculating the effective annual rate that First United Bank is the favorable bank since the compounding period is shorter, resulting in a lower effective rate.
